main.java.enigma

Class Plugboard

  • java.lang.Object
    • main.java.enigma.Plugboard

  • public class Plugboard
extends java.lang.Object
    This class simulates the plugboard in the Enigma encryption machine. The plugboard was a simple two-way replacement cipher that was available on some Enigmas. The substitions were performed both during initial letter input (before processing by rotors and reflectors) and output (after processing). Plugboards are represented through a string that indicates their replacement mapping. Letters are swapped with their adjacent letters. For example, a string of "ABCD" swaps A's with B's (and vice-versa) and C's with D's.
    Version:
    0.9 - Nov 22, 2013
    Author:
    Brian Matthew Winstead, Team Enigma

    • Constructor Detail

      • Plugboard

        public Plugboard(java.lang.String mapping)
        Constructor. Accepts a string of characters and creates a simple two-way replacement cipher. The string should be formatted in pairs with no spaces or punctuation. The constructor does not check the capitalization of the input and does not remove punctuation, spaces, or invalid characters. The constructor does not prevent double-mapping, although the first match will always be the one returned.
        Parameters:
        mapping - String to be used to create the two-way substitution. Strings are not checked for validity.

      • Plugboard

        public Plugboard(char[][] newpb)
        Constructor. Builds a two-way substitution cipher out of a two-dimensional array. Characters in the first row will be swapped with their corresponding characters in the second row, and vice-versa. For example, the character in newpb[0][0] will get swapped with newpb[0][1], and vice- versa.
        Parameters:
        newpb - Two-dimensional array of characters representing the plugboard configuration. Input is not checked for validity.

    • Method Detail

      • getPlugboardMap

        public java.lang.String getPlugboardMap()
        Returns the current plugboard map to the machine, which then passes it where needed.
        Returns:
        String representing the current plugboard map.

      • matchChar

        public char matchChar(char c)
        Checks a character to see if it's a swap-character. If so, it returns the substitution character. If not, it returns the initial character.
        Parameters:
        c - Character to be checked for substitution.
        Returns:
        The substitution character if there is a match. If not, return is the original character.
